questions.text: Vaginal epithelium is derived from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Development of the vagina is composite, partly from the Müllerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts) and partly from the urogenital sinus.

Vaginal Epithelium

The vagina is lined by stratified squamous epithelium, which is composed of the following types of cells:

  • Parabasal/basal cells: These are predominant when there is no hormonal dominance.
  • Intermediate cells: These are predominant when there is progesterone predominance, i.e. in the luteal phase/latter half of the menstrual cycle.
  • Superficial cells: These are predominant when there is estrogen predominance, i.e. in the follicular phase, first half of the menstrual cycle.
  • The intermediate and superficial cells contain glycogen under the influence of estrogen. In Newborn females, the vagina is lined by transitional epithelium.

Explanation of other options:

Mesoderm of the urogenital sinus (Option B): The urogenital sinus is derived from the endoderm, not mesoderm.

Endoderm of the genital ridge (Option C): The genital ridge contributes to gonadal development, not vaginal epithelium.

Mesoderm of the genital ridge (Option D): The genital ridge mesoderm gives rise to gonads (ovaries/testes), not vaginal epithelium.

choices.text: Lymphatic from the clitoris drains to the ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph nodes
Traverse the labia from medial to lateral
Drain directly into deep femoral glands

questions.text: Which of the following about the lymphatics of the vulva is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Special features of vulval lymphatics are as follows:

  • Superficial lymph nodes are the primary lymph nodes that act as sentinel glands of the vulva. Deep inguinal nodes are secondarily involved. It is unusual to find pelvic glands without metastasis in the inguinal nodes. Hence, they traverse the labia from the medial to the lateral side.
  • Lymphatic drainage from the clitoris, anterior labia minora, and perineum is bilateral. Metastases to contralateral lymph nodes in the absence of ipsilateral nodal involvement are very rare for a lateral vulval tumour less than 2cm. (Option A ruled out)
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross at the mons pubis and the posterior fourchette but do not cross the labiocrural folds. (Option D ruled out)
  • The lymphatics of the vulva and distal third of the vagina typically drain into the superficial inguinal node group. From here, lymph travels through the deep femoral lymphatics and the node of Cloquet to the pelvic nodal groups. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: The Narrowest part of the fallopian tube is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Parts are as follows,

  • Interstitium (Intramural): 1.25 cm long and 1 mm in diameter (narrowest part). It has no longitudinal muscles; only circular muscles are present and act as an anatomical sphincter.
  • Isthmus: 2.5 cm long and 2 mm in diameter (second narrowest part); acts as a physiologic sphincter. (Option B ruled out)
  • Ampulla: Widest and longest part (5 cm), and fertilisation occurs here. (Option D ruled out)
  • Fimbriae/infundibulum: 1.25 cm long with a maximum diameter of 6 mm. Total length = 4 inches or 10-12 cm. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Blood supply of the fallopian tube:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fallopian tube:

  • Blood supply:
    • Medial: 2/3rd by the uterine artery
    • Lateral: 1/3rd by ovarian artery
  • Lymphatic drainage: The Lateral part, along with the ovarian lymphatic, drains into the lateral aortic LN. The medial part, along with the cornua, drains into the superficial inguinal LN.
  • Histologically:
    • The fallopian tube is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with a unique type of cell called a Peg cell, whose function is not known. It also has secretory cells whose secretions are rich in pyruvate. The early conceptus derives its nutrition from pyruvate.

Explanation of other options:

Simpson's artery (Option C), also called Simpson's artery, is a small anastomotic artery between the uterine and ovarian arteries.
It runs along the round ligament of the uterus, especially in the inguinal canal portion.

questions.text: What is the typical uterus-to-cervix length ratio (corpus: cervix) in childhood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The uterus-to-cervix length ratio (corpus: cervix) varies by age and hormonal status.
  • In childhood, the cervix is disproportionately longer than the uterine corpus, leading to a 1:2 ratio.
  • This reverses at puberty due to hormonal influence, particularly estrogen, which causes uterine corpus growth.

(Options A, B and C ruled out)

questions.text: Bartholin's cyst is caused by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bartholin's cyst:
    • It is the most common cyst of the vulva.
    • Bartholins' cysts are produced from the accumulation of secretions of Bartholin's gland.
    • The cyst may develop either in the duct (more common) or in the gland
    • Aetiology: Cyst formation occurs due to the obstruction of the main duct or opening of an acinus.
    • The cause of obstruction is usually fibrosis, which follows either infection or trauma.
    • The most common organism associated with aetiology is Escherichia coli, followed by Gonococci.
    • The left side of Bartholin's gland is more often affected than the right.
  • Presentation:
    • Usually presents as a unilateral swelling that bulges across the vaginal introitus.
    • The size of the cyst rarely exceeds that of a hen's egg.
    • Swelling is present characteristically on the inner side of the junction of the anterior 2/3rd with the posterior 1/3rd of the labium majus.
    • The swelling is fluctuant and usually non-tender
    • Patients may present with discomfort, dyspareunia, or infection. The treatment of choice is Marsupialisation: It is preferred over traditional excision operations.

Explanation of other options:

Candida (Option A): Rarely implicated in Bartholin's cyst; more common in vulvovaginitis.

Anaerobes (Option B): Anaerobes may contribute to Bartholin's abscess, but are not the most common primary cause of the cyst.

Trichomonas (Option D): Not a typical pathogen for Bartholin's gland cysts.

questions.text: Glands of Littre are homologous to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The glands of the labia minora are homologous to the glands of Littre (Glandulas prepuciales) of the penile portion of the male urethra
  • Skene's tubules are the paraurethral glands equivalent to the prostate in males. Both Bartholin's glands and Skene's tubules arise as downgrowths of the urogenital sinus. (Option C ruled out)
  • Bartholin's Glands are homologous to Cowper's gland/bulbourethral glands in males.
  • They are 2 in number and of racemose type.
    • Lie in the superficial perineal pouch embedded in the posterior part of the vestibular bulb.
    • Glands are oval and are the size of a pea.
  • They are impalpable unless enlarged.
    • The acini are lined by a single layer of low columnar or cuboidal cells. (Option A ruled out)
  • Labia majora are homologous to the scrotum.

questions.text: The uterine artery is a direct branch of which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The uterine artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery. In cases of uncontrollable PPH, the uterine artery or the anterior division of the internal iliac artery can be ligated to stop further blood loss.
  • Uterine Artery
    • As a terminal branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery, the uterine artery runs downwards and medially to cross the ureter near the cervix (2 cm lateral to the cervix). It then ascends along the lateral border of the uterus in a tortuous course, giving branches to both uterine surfaces.
    • 2 cm lateral to the cervix, where it crosses the ureter, is called water under the bridge (bridge-artery, water-urine in the ureter). This is the most common site of ureteric injury during hysterectomy, followed by the pelvic brim.

Branches of the uterine artery to the uterus:

U = Uterine artery

A = Arcuate artery supplies the outer 1/3rd of the myometrium

R = Radial artery supplies the inner 2/3rd of the myometrium

B = Basal artery supplies the basal endometrium

S = Spiral artery supplies the superficial endometrium

Explanation of other options:

Aorta (Option A): Gives rise to the common iliac arteries but not directly to the uterine artery.

Common iliac (Option B): Divides into internal and external iliac arteries; does not directly give a uterine branch.

External iliac (Option D): Supplies the lower limb, not involved in uterine supply.

Key Takeaways:

  • Uterine artery = anterior division of the internal iliac artery
  • Ureteric crossing = important surgical landmark (2 cm lateral to the cervix)
  • The blood supply of the uterus has collateral support via ovarian and vaginal arteries.

questions.text: For assessment of hormonal status through vaginal cytology, the sample should be taken from which wall of the vagina?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vaginal study gives a fair idea about the hormonal status and, in turn, about the ovulation/ovarian cycle.
    • For a hormonal study, the sample should be taken from the lateral wall
    • For a cytological study (Pap smear), the sample should be taken from the posterior wall. (Option B ruled out)
  • Squamous epithelium is resistant to gonococcal infection; hence, theoretically, gonococcal vaginitis can occur in newborn females
    • Vagina does not have any mucus-secreting glands.
  • Since the vagina does not have any glands, vaginal discharge is not derived from the vagina.
  • The components of vaginal secretion are derived from:
    • Endocervical glands
    • Endometrial glands
    • Bartholin's glands
  • The vagina does not have any serosal covering except for the area covered by the cul-de-sac posteriorly.
  • Apart from Doderlein's bacilli, it contains many other pathogenic organisms, including Clostridium welchii.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior wall (Option A): Not ideal due to less representative cell maturity and increased risk of contamination.

Any wall (Option D): The Lateral wall is specifically recommended for consistency and reliability.

questions.text: Vaginal defence is lost:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vaginal defence is lost 10 days after birth.
  • The maternal estrogen circulating in the newborn maintains the vaginal defence for 10 days. (Option A ruled out)
  • Thereafter, it is lost up to pre-puberty and after menopause.
  • High levels of circulating estrogen increase the vaginal defence during puberty, pregnancy and in the premenstrual phase. (Options C and D ruled out)

questions.text: The triangular area bounded by the clitoris, the fourchette, and the labia minora is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The vestibule is the triangular area bounded anteriorly by the clitoris, posteriorly by the Fourchette and on either side by the labia minora. It contains the openings of:
    • Urethra
    • Vagina
    • Ducts of Bartholin's glands
    • Ducts of Skene's glands
  • Mons Pubis (Veneris):Pad of subcutaneous adipose connective tissue lying in front of the pubis and the adult female covered by hair.
  • Labia Majora: Lie on either side; join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure. Their inner side is hairless. It is homologous to the scrotum in a male. The round ligament terminates at its anterior third.
    • Contains the hair follicles and the sebaceous glands.
  • Labia Minora:They are two thick folds of skin, devoid of fat, lying within the labia majora. Anteriorly, they enclose the clitoris and unite with each other in front and behind the clitoris to form the prepuce and the frenulum, respectively.
  • The lower portion of the labia fuses across the midline to form a fold of skin called thefourchette. It is homologous to the ventral aspect of the penis. (Option B ruled out)
  • Clitoris: It is a small erectile body (2.5 cm) lying in the anteriormost part of the vulva. It is homologous to the male penis. It consists of the glans, a body and two crura.
  • Fossa navicularis: It is the shallow depression posterior to the vaginal opening, not the triangular space described. (Option A ruled out).
  • Vulva: Refers to all external female genitalia, including mons pubis, labia majora and minor, clitoris, and vestibule. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Distance between the vulva and the labia minora

questions.text: Where is the Fourchette?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fourchette: Posteriorly, where the labia minora meet
  • Fossa Navicular: The Distance between the hymen and the fourchette
  • Posterior Commissure - Posteriorly, where the labia majora meet. (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Labia minora and majora meet (Option C): These structures do not unite; labia minora lie medial to majora.

Distance between vulva and labia minora (Option D): Incorrect anatomical description. No such defined structure.

questions.text: All are related to the lateral vaginal fornix except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The inferior vesical artery mainly supplies the bladder base and trigone. It lies anteriorly and is not related to the lateral fornix.
  • The cervix and all 4 fornices are related to
    • Uterine Vessels (Option D)
    • Mackenrodt's ligament (Option B)
    • Ureter (Option A)
  • Posteriorly surrounding the Pouch of Douglas lie the uterosacral ligaments.

choices.text: Makes an angle of 45°with the horizontal in an erect posture
Looks like the letter 'H' on the cross-section
Vaginal axis lies parallel to the uterus and at a right angle to the plane of the pelvic inlet
Is lined by stratified squamous epithelium

questions.text: All are correct about the vagina except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The long axis of the vagina almost lies parallel to the plane of the pelvic inlet and at right angles to that of the uterus (not vice versa).
  • The canal is directed upwards and backwards, forming an angle of 45° with the horizontal in an erect posture. (Option A explained).
  • Vagina has an anterior, a posterior, and two lateral walls and is lined by stratified squamous epithelium. (Option D explained)
  • The anterior and posterior walls are opposed together, but the lateral walls are comparatively stiff, especially in their middle; as such, they look 'H' shaped on the transverse section. (Option B explained)

choices.text: A groove between the labia minora and the hymen

questions.text: Bartholin's duct opens into:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ducts of the Bartholin gland are 2 cm long and open into the vestibule outside the hymen at the junction of the anterior 2/3rd and posterior 1/3rd in the groove between the hymen and labia minora.
  • Bartholin's glands are pea-sized oval glands in females, homologous to Cowper's Gland in males. Bulbourethral glands in males.
  • The duct as well gland is lined by multilayered columnar epithelium (Not by transitional epithelium as is usually stated).
  • The function of the gland is to produce abundant alkaline mucus during sexual excitement.

Explanation of other options:

Labia majora and minora (Option A): The duct does not open between these structures.

The lower vagina(Option C): This is anatomically incorrect and not the site of the duct opening.

The upper vagina(Option D): Bartholin's duct does not communicate with the vaginal canal.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site where peg cells are found?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Histologically, the Fallopian tube is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with a unique type of cell called a Peg cell, whose function is not known.
  • It also has secretory cells whose secretions are rich in pyruvate. The early conceptus derives its nutrition from pyruvate.
  • Blood supply:
    • Medial: 2/3rd by the uterine artery
    • Lateral: 1/3rd by ovarian artery
  • Lymphatic drainage:
    • The Lateral part, along with ovarian lymphatics, drains into the lateral aortic LN.
    • The medial part, along with the cornua, drains into the superficial inguinal LN.

Explanation of other options:

Vagina (Option A): Lined by stratified squamous epithelium, with no secretory peg cells.

Vulva (Option B): Also covered by keratinised squamous epithelium, not columnar or secretory.

Ovary (Option C): Contains stromal and germinal epithelial cells, with no peg cells present.

questions.text: What is the normal length of the ureter in adult females?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The total length of the ureter is 25 cm
  • The length of the pelvic ureter is around 13-15 cm.
  • The diameter is 5mm.
  • The ureter enters the pelvis in front of the bifurcation of the common iliac artery, anterior to the sacroiliac joint.
  • As it courses downwards, it lies anterior to the internal iliac artery, medial to the obturator nerves and vessels and forms the posterior boundary of the ovarian fossa.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles are attached to the perineal body?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The perineal body (central tendon of the perineum) is a fibromuscular body placed in the median plane at the junction of the anal and urogenital triangles.
  • It is pyramidal and has all three layers of muscles, i.e.
    • Levator ani
    • Deep transverse perineum
    • Superficial muscles except Ischiocavernosus
    • External anal sphincter
    • Bulbospongiosus
    • Part of the longitudinal muscle of the rectum

(All options explained)

questions.text: What is the normal difference in length between the anterior and posterior vaginal walls?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anterior wall = 7.5 cm, posterior wall = 9 cm in length.

Vagina

  • A distensible fibromuscular canal connecting the uterine cavity with the exterior of the vulva. Anterior wall = 5 cm, posterior wall = 9 cm in length.
  • The upper vagina is separated by the cervix into anterior, posterior and lateral fornices.
  • Deepest fornix = posterior fornix; Shallowest fornix = anterior fornix.
  • On cut section = It is H-shaped
  • The cervixand all 4 fornices are related to:
    • Uterine vessels
    • Mackenrodt's ligament
    • Ureter
    • Vagina

choices.text: Where it is crossed by the uterine artery
Where it is over the obturator

questions.text: What is the most common site of ureteric injury during gynaecological surgeries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Site of ureteric injury during hysterectomy :
    • The most common site = is where it is crossed by the uterine artery
    • 2nd most common site= Near pelvic brim
  • Pelvic ureter
    • It extends from its crossing over the pelvic brim up to its opening into the bladder.
    • Measures 13-15 cm in length and has a diameter of 5 mm.
    • The ureter enters the pelvis in front of the bifurcation of the common iliac artery, anterior to the sacroiliac joint. As it courses downwards, it lies anterior to the internal iliac artery, medial to the obturator nerves and vessels and forms the posterior boundary of the ovarian fossa.
    • On reaching the ischial spine, it lies over the pelvic floor, and as it courses forwards and medially on the base of the broad ligament, it is crossed by the uterine artery anteriorly.
    • Soon, it enters the ureteric tunnel and lies close to the supravaginal part of the cervix, about 1.5 cm lateral to it.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Pelvic brim (Option A): This is the second most common site, not the first.

Where it enters the bladder (Option C): Less commonly injured in gynaecological surgeries.

Where it is over the obturator (Option D): Rarely involved in injury during standard gynaecological procedures.

Key Takeaway:

During a hysterectomy, always identify the ureter crossing under the uterine artery ("water under the bridge") to avoid injury.
